content:
These are emoticons not emoji

Emoji are characters pictograms given special unicode code points for encoding them explictly from the unicode system (which derive from a set of pictogram symbols supported by the Japanese NTT Docomo for use in messaging), whereas emoticons repurpose existing characters such as letters and symbols.

Validator 5 is your only test with a space character.
This is bad for shortest mode, because you can appear to be getting 100% on the test cases using split on the input to break the face from the arm, but then only get 80% on the validators...

I suggest adding a space in a test case or swapping test "Good Faces" with validator 5. Hidden edge cases are very annoying in shortest mode.

Nice, short clash.
My Python 3 sol:
def reversed(s):
    s=s[::-1]
    Fat = { '<':'>','>':'<', 
            '/':'\\','\\':'/',
            '[':']',']':'[',
            '{':'}','}':'{',
            '(':')',')':'('}
    # return ''.join([Fat[i] if i in Fat else i for i in s])
    return ''.join(map(lambda x:(Fat[x]if x in Fat else x),s))

face = input()
arm = input()
print(f'{arm}{face}{reversed(arm)}')

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is a nice graphical exercise, not too hard to deal with characters

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice one, it could be cool in both shortest code and reverse mode

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I liked it. Fresh! Here is my Python solution.

d = {
    '<':'>',
    '>':'<',
    '/':'\\',
    '\\':'/',
    '[':']',
    ']':'[',
    '{':'}',
    '}':'{',
    '(':')',
    ')':'(',
}

face = input()
arm = input()
right_arm = ''.join([d[e] if e in d else e for e in arm][::-1])
print(arm + face + right_arm)
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
I liked it, congratulations on the effort of always posting new clashs, people like you help the community a lot!

"Output a bracket emoji with it's face and it's left arm."
This suggests that the output has three parts: emoji, face and left arm
The face and left arm are the input
Suggestion: "Given a bracket emoji's face and left arm, print the whole emoji."

---

"reverse the characters"
It is not clear if this means:
- reverse the order of the characters (change "ABC" to "CBA")
- mirror special characters (change ">" to "<")
- reverse the order of characters AND mirror special characters
Suggestion:
"To make the right arm:
- reverse the order of the characters in the left arm
- replace the following special characters with the mirrored version:
[list of special characters]"

---

"All brackets reverse."
I would explicitly state that this includes:
[] brackets
{} braces
() parentheses
(Depending on the version of English spoken, these may not all be called "brackets")

---

Good faces. (test) and Validator 5 (validator) include unicode characters which some languages cannot handle.
I edited it a bit but you might still want to change it. Can you also now check that good faces and validator 5 now work because I only know python
